comments: Just recorded lecture.
just recorded lectures.
Office hours

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Introductory concepts in statistics and an introduction to R.
Learned a lot about statistics and also a little bit of R.
Statistics and coding with R
A great course to introduce yourself to statistics and data analysis.
I learned the basics of statistics and how to code using r.
How to program in R and create linear models from datasets in R.
I learned how to understand and model data sets.
An introduction to statistics
Basic statistics

S&DS 100 UMB: I have a somewhat better understanding of basic statistics and where to start when analyzing a dataset. I know now how to read a normal quantile plot and how to evaluate a linear model. I know a few different types of distributions now, including Poisson and binomial and how to differentiate between the two. 

S&DS 106: Got more familiar with building linear regression models in R. I think my biggest takeaway is just a better understanding of basic commands in R. Not too much development of the base statistics that we learned in the first half, but more application-based.

I gained a basic understanding of general statistics principles (probability, sampling distributions, chi-square, regression), as well as the ability to write simple R code to create plots, charts, linear models, etc. We also got to create a simple final project at the end where we used R to build a linear model.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Because the lectures were recorded and asynchronous it was easy to fall behind and also a bit difficult to get to know the professors. Either way, JDRS was funny and engaging so the class was good overall. I believe the class overall can be improved by having a synchronous component to the class to hold students accountable in some way.
Weaknesses: the lectures can sometimes be dry and the quizzes were a lot more difficult than the homework assignments. Strengths: the professors are very responsive to emails and questions.
It was completely asynchronous which was nice.

The course was structured really well. I have never taken a statistics course or even chapter before and I was able to understand and follow all the material really well due to the structure of the course

This class did a good job explaining all of the necessary material. I was able to grasp everything and do the problem sets easily for the most part. In terms of how the class was run, there weren't really any weak points.

Strengths: you learn through hands-on handling of datasets
Weaknesses: if you want to learn more advanced stuff, you have to take intiative to do it since this class is an intro class. Not necessarily a weakness.

I thought that the course was super informative and helpful for improving my statistics understanding. However, I thought there were times when the class moved a little quickly. There were times when material on tests were only briefly addressed in lecture. Moreover, there were many times when the amount of recorded lecture time exceeded the alotted class time. Sometimes these overtime lecture, combined with the density of class material, made it hard to keep up.
Liked how you could complete it on your own time; very organized weekly modules
The course was very well paced and allowed for much exploration through its p-sets.

Strengths: JDRS and the overall organization. This was hands-down the cleanest Canvas page I've ever seen for a course. Truly impressive. All of the material was organized and easy to follow. The lectures were pretty engaging, too. I think the thing I appreciated the most was the emphasis on learning over the grade. No idea how I actually did in the course, but just overall the atmosphere seemed geared toward teaching the main concepts and not nit-picking which was very much appreciated.

Weaknesses: Had a couple of homework problems that were graded incorrectly and I didn't catch them until it was too late to go back and ask for a regrade. Things like getting a negative number where the solutions said it should be a positive number, and the only reason for that was switching the order of the inputs. I know it's a minor detail, but it's a bit frustrating to have to re-check the TAs work to make sure that it's fair.

Strengths: JDRS is a great lecturer w/clear and insightful notes, the course is very well organized and predictable, TAs are extremely helpful with psets, I feel like I was able to gain a good understanding of important statistical principles, the exams are fair, Professor Khusainova is very kind and approachable, she explains R code really well and also has organized notes, office hours are run well, the workload is manageable and gets pretty light towards the end
Weaknesses: would've liked a little more practice; the psets were clearly designed for Minitab users, so it was hard to learn R then, HW grading can be slightly nitpicky (but only a few points will be taken off)

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Recorded lectures were helpful.

I thought the recorded lectures helped me because I was able to watch them at any time and work them around my schedule. With that being said, it was sometimes hard to engage since there wasn't a teacher actually there in real time.

I liked that there was an abundance of available office hour times. I would definitely continue that practice in the future. Moreover, I feel like it might be helpful to have a couple practice problems available prior to exams.
Enjoyed the pre-recorded lectures; office hours were helpful as well
The recorded lectures were great as they were all relatively short and so packed with information to keep them interesting.

Nothing can really be changed; the online learning environment sucks. Given the restrictions though, I do think that JDRS, Professor Khusainova, and all of the TAs made the most of a poor situation. I appreciate the effort that they put in, even if, at the end of the day, watching recorded lectures and going to Zoom office hours just can't replace engaging in person.

The pre-recorded lectures and overall format of the class was already well-adapted to online learning before the COVID-19 pandemic, so everything ran really smoothly. I don't have many complaints besides the fact that I would've liked a few more online review sessions, but overall it was really good.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. I took this class to learn about basic concepts in statistics and to learn to code in R. Although I did learn the basic statistics concepts, the R component of the class was really short (two lectures to introduce R and two lectures to learn statistics in R). If your main objective is to learn R, I would recommend to look into other classes. Otherwise, this class is fun and engaging and a low workload with a good grading scheme.
I would recommend this course if you want to get a basic understanding of statistics and learn about how to code in R; however, this course isn't a gut class.
Yes, it is good for a student with a heavy course load.

This course is great in breaking the barrier into statistics and data analysis. This course breaks everything down to the simplest concepts and improves your understanding. You get a solid foundation.
Yes, I would. It was very intellectually challenging and it thought me skills that may be helpful later in life.
Yes! R is very useful and its very fun.
Yes, especially if you plan to take econometrics or another stats class in the future.
Absolutely, my favorite class I have taken so far.
Yes great course for learning basic stats
Yes
Yes, its a great introduction to R.

Yes. This course is fair. Truly. The expectations are clear, there are tons of office hours if you need help, JDRS is personable and teaches clearly, and the exams/homework are intended to test the material that you learn. There really aren't any traps here. What you see is what you get. If you're looking for a better understanding of basic statistics or even just a bit more practice, then this course is for you. 

I will say that I struggled sometimes to find time to learn the material, but I think that had more to do with my lecture-watching habits and not being able to engage in person than with any deficiencies in the course or instruction. 

Basically, take it. You'll be fine.

I'd recommend this course to students who don't have much of a background in statistics or would like to get a refresher on important statistical topics. I didn't take AP Stat or any statistics courses before this course, so I feel like I was able to learn a lot! I also really enjoyed being able to learn how to code simple things in R.
